From: Rosero, Gerald (Records) <GRosero@records.nyc.gov>
Sent: Thursday, May 8, 2025 2:06 PM
To: SusanZhuang43 <susanzhuang43@council.nyc.gov>
Subject: Updating email contact information for Council Members

Good Afternoon Council Member Zhuang
Our department is currently updating the contact information for council members. Can you please let us know if this is your council email, if not can you please provide our department with your official council email.
Thank You
Gerald Rosero

column4: RE: Appreciation and IS 187 Spring Gala
column5:
Tuesday, May 21, 2025

Is it Tuesday ?  Or Wednesday
May 21, 2025

Stanley Ng
Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang
6514-20th Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11204
Phone:  718-307-7151

From: Wilhelmina Sadiki <WSadiki@schools.nyc.gov>
Sent: Thursday, May 8, 2025 9:23 AM
To: Zhuang, Susan <szhuang@council.nyc.gov>; Xie, Joyce <JXie@council.nyc.gov>; Ng, Stanley <SNg@council.nyc.gov>
Subject: Appreciation and IS 187 Spring Gala

Dear Council Member Zhuang and Team,
On behalf of the students, families, and staff of The Christa McAuliffe School, IS 187, I want to extend our sincere appreciation for your steadfast support and advocacy. We are especially grateful for your help in bringing the BIO Bus to our school, it was an exciting and enriching experience for our students. Once we confirm the afterschool date, we would be honored to welcome you again to see the program in action.
It is in this same spirit of gratitude that we would be truly delighted to welcome you and your outstanding team as our guests at our upcoming Annual Spring Gala. This celebration recognizes the people and partnerships like yours that make a lasting impact on our school community.
Event Details:
Event: IS 187 Annual Spring Gala
Date: Tuesday, May 21, 2025
Time: 6:30 PM � 10:00 PM
Location: Bay Ridge Manor
476 76th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11209
Your presence would mean so much to our families, and staff. We hope you will join us for an evening of celebration, community, and appreciation.
Please let us know if you and your team will be able to attend. We would be thrilled for you an your team to attend.
With gratitude,
Mina Sadiki
Principal
The Christa McAuliffe School, IS 187

column4: (05/08/2025) - PURCHASE ORDER FOR (CM S. ZHUANG, DO# 43)
column5:
We received the polos.

Here�s the photos

Stanley Ng
Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang
6514-20th Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11204
Phone:  718-307-7151

From: Alladice, Fahja <FAlladice@council.nyc.gov>
Sent: Friday, April 11, 2025 9:32 AM
To: 'Jagugprinting@gmail.com' <Jagugprinting@gmail.com>
Cc: Baldwin, Jenna <JBaldwin@council.nyc.gov>; Merizalde, Freddy <FMerizalde@council.nyc.gov>; Ng, Stanley <SNg@council.nyc.gov>; Pirzada, Maham <MPirzada@council.nyc.gov>
Subject: PURCHASE ORDER FOR (CM S. ZHUANG, DO# 43)

Good morning,

Please see attachment for invoice# 4825A for PO# 20252025546.

If you have any questions, feel free to email.


Fahja Alladice
New York City Council
250 Broadway, 16th Floor
P: 212-482-5160
Purchasing Coordinator
FAlladice@council.nyc.gov<mailto:FAlladice@council.nyc.gov>

At the moment, there nothing else that can be done.  Based on the last 4/23/2025 inspection, I doubt that NYC DOH will make another inspection this soon unless there's proof (this is the reason why we check the RATS Portal information first).


My suggestion is to please get NYC DSNY involved and force the owner to get that space cleaned first.


Stanley Ng

Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang

6514-20th Avenue

Brooklyn, NY 11204

Phone:  718-307-7151

Hi Bridget,



We do offer certificates of recognition for high school seniors.  We would just need to know how many students and a list of their names.  Also, if there is an awards ceremony you would like the Council Member to stop by at, let me know the date and time of that as well.  Let me know if you have any further questions.



Regards,



Xavier San Miguel

Subject: Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP)
Importance: High

Good afternoon,

We are aware that a number of Member Offices would like to apply or may have applied in the past to partner with local organizations to bring Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP) participants to work at their Council offices during the summer. To the extent any Member Offices would be interested in applying for the summer of 2025, please take note of the below.

SYEP participants would be unpaid staff at the Council and must be processed prior to working at your offices. Please contact UnpaidStaff@council.nyc.gov<mailto:UnpaidStaff@council.nyc.gov> to schedule onboarding for any unpaid staff.

If you have already applied to be an SYEP worksite in 2025, please email Lucinda Cardinal in Personnel Services at lcardinal@council.nyc.gov<mailto:lcardinal@council.nyc.gov> with the following information:

�              The name of your SYEP participant supervisor for your office.

�              Number of SYEP participants that you have requested.

�              A copy of any documents you may have signed in connection with your application.

If you have not yet applied to be a SYEP worksite in 2025 and would like to host SYEP participants during the summer of 2025, please email Lucinda Cardinal in Personnel Services at lcardinal@council.nyc.gov<mailto:lcardinal@council.nyc.gov> .

In addition, you and your chiefs-of-staff will be receiving a calendar invite from Lucinda Cardinal to a virtual information session to be held on Friday, April 4, 2025, hosted by DYCD Workforce Connect, to share more about the SYEP program, how to apply to be a worksite, and to answer your questions.

Thank you


Camille A. Francis
Director | Personnel Services Division

Office: (212) 788-6931
Cell:     (917) 558-3214
eFax:   12124014711

New York City Council
250 Broadway, 26th Floor
New York, New York 10007

Hi Dmytro,

Thank you for contacting our office about this matter. I checked the 311 number you mentioned (#311-22698454) and it is not showing up in the system. It might be missing one digit, please double-check it, or file a new complaint here: Click to Report Housing Used for Short-Term Rental<https://portal.311.nyc.gov/sr-step/?id=ca9fbed9-1f25-f011-9d48-7c1e529ce39b&stepid=749ab462-2a52-e811-a836-000d3a33b56b>. Importance: High



From: Dima Makogon <dima@makogon.us<mailto:dima@makogon.us>>
Sent: Monday, April 28, 2025 4:44 PM
To: Zhuang, Susan <szhuang@council.nyc.gov<mailto:szhuang@council.nyc.gov>>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Illegal Hostel Operation at 44 Bay 41st Street, 1st FLOOR, Brooklyn, NY 11214� Request for Investigation


CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Report suspected phishing emails with the Phish Alert Button or forward them to phish@oti.nyc.gov<mailto:phish@oti.nyc.gov> as an attachment.



Dear Councilmember Susan Zhuang,



I am a resident of 44 Bay 41st Street, 2nd FLOOR Brooklyn, NY 11214 and I am writing to report an illegal hostel or transient short-term rental operation on the first floor of our building.



The Certificate of Occupancy clearly designates the first floor for one-family use. However, the apartment has been divided into multiple rooms (each labeled Room 1, Room 2, Room 3, etc.), and there is a constant turnover of short-term renters carrying luggage in and out. I have collected evidence, including photographs of the room numbers inside the unit and records of frequent visitor activity.



This illegal operation has caused significant disturbances, including excessive noise (especially late at night), fire and safety concerns due to overcrowding, and a general decline in the quality of life for residents.



I have previously filed complaints with 311. [SR SUBMITTED #311-22698454 ] which was filed on 4/25/25 but the issue continues for approximately 2 years when I rented the apartment. But landlord told me only about one person who lives downstairs (1st floor). Now the situation is very serious because these people downstairs started to play clips with crazy noises on the repeat and very loud to provoke me and my family but my mom who lives with me and my 11 yo daughter cannot handle it anymore. They are very scared and my mom started to have health issues because of the constant stress� Our landlord CANNOT do anything about it maybe he allows this to happen , these people on the first floor didn�t even let the landlord inside when I asked him to come (I even have the video of this incident) and listen to the crazy sounds(I recorded it also) they were playing on purpose to put us on stress. I constantly Texting and Calling landlord to make something about it but most of the time he didn�t even respond (I have all the evidence about it )



I respectfully request that the Department of Buildings and the Office of Special Enforcement investigate this matter urgently and take all necessary enforcement actions to restore the legal and safe use of the premises.



Thank you for your attention to this serious issue.



Sincerely,

Dmytro Makogon

44 Bay 41st Street,

Brooklyn, NY 11214

(646)258-9415

Dima@makogon.us<mailto:Dima@makogon.us>

Subject: RE: Lien Sale 10 Day Notice List
?

Hello Council Members & Staff,



Attached is the updated 10-day list of properties at risk of having their tax liens sold on May 20. As usual, the list can be filtered by Council district using the filtering function in Excel.



At this point, almost 30 percent of the 29,000 properties originally at risk of having liens sold have resolved their status and have been removed from the list, bringing it down to about 18,000 properties.



In prior lien sales, the final 10 days generally sees the biggest number of resolutions with another 40 percent of the properties resolving their debt at this last stage, either through payments, payment plans, exemptions, or other actions. In other words, over half the activity of removing a property from the lien sale often occurs in the last 10 days. So your offices may expect to see more activity from constituents on this list in these final days.



As always, please do not hesitate to reach out if you have questions.



Thank you,

Emre

Emre Edev (he/him)
Deputy Director
New York City Council, Finance Division
212-482-2915

Subject: Lien Sale 90 Day Notice List

Hello Council Members & Staff,

This year�s Lien Sale will be held in May. To avoid being included in the lien sale, all property owners must take actions to resolve their delinquency by May 19. PLEASE ENCOURAGE YOUR CONSTITUENTS TO EITHER: 1) PAY AT LEAST THE MINIMUM AMOUNT OWED, 2) APPLY FOR AN EXEMPTION, OR 3) ENTER INTO A PAYMENT AGREEMENT TO PREVENT INCLUSION INTO THE LIEN SALE!

Attached is an excel sheet of the 90 day list for properties noticed for sale for the 2025 Lien Sale.  Notices have also been mailed to affected property owners. The notice will include charges owed, payment agreement information, and information on certain property tax exemptions (Senior Citizen Home Owner Exemption, Disable Homeowner Exemption, Circuit Breaker Exemption) and other programs like Easy Exit that can exclude a property owner from the lien sale. Keep in mind that the recent legislation created multiple ways for an owner to resolve their delinquency beyond just paying their debt, so an owner should explore all options before making a decision before the May 19 deadline. More information on the numerous resolution options is in the attached factsheet.


The attached list is sortable and contains the following information:

�         Borough, Block, Lot

�         Council District

�         Tax Class code

�         Building Class

�         Street Address and Zip Code

�         Amount Owed � both Total owed, and amount nee

�         Charge type

I will send additional lists at the 60 and 30 day marks prior to the May 19 last day to pay date.

More information about the lien sale, including already scheduled outreach sessions is located here: http://www1.nyc.gov/site/finance/taxes/property-lien-sales.page

Additional information can be found in the email I sent on Tuesday, February 4.

Please reach out with any questions,
Thanks
Emre

Subject: Save the Date: January 30 - Property Tax Enforcement Briefing for Constituent Facing Staff


Hello Council Members & Staff,



On Thursday, January 30, from 3-4 pm, the Department of Finance, along with sister agencies, will provide Council Members and Staff a virtual briefing (link to come) of the upcoming 2025 Property Tax Enforcement efforts. This briefing will include information that your offices can share with constituents to know all the ways they can resolve their delinquency status and prevent their inclusion in this year�s lien sale.



What is the Lien Sale?

When property owners fail to pay property taxes, water bills, and other charges against their property, and the debts remain unpaid for long enough, these unpaid charges become tax liens that become subject to heightened enforcement action. If a property's delinquency status is not resolved in time, the liens on the property can be sold to a Trust that is created and controlled by the City. If the Trust is unable to resolve the debt with the owner, it can begin foreclosure proceedings.



How can a property or homeowner avoid the Lien Sale?

Local Law 82 of 2024 implemented the largest reforms to the City's tax lien sale process since it first was created nearly 30 years ago. These reforms included including creating numerous and overlapping ways for homeowners to resolve their delinquency status and avoid the lien sale. Many of these resolutions, including installment plans and tax deferrals, do not require any down payments. The briefing will review all the different ways to avoid the lien sale. The goal is to collect delinquent revenues from property owners who have the means to pay, while providing long-term solutions to at-risk homeowners who are struggling.



When's the Lien Sale?

This year�s lien sale will take place in May. The 90-day notification to property owners will be mailed on February 12 by the Department of Finance. Your offices will be provided the list of property owners who have received the notice.



Briefing Information



Date: Thursday, January 30, 2025



Time: 3PM-4PM



Where: Virtual (link to come)



If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact me.



Thank you,



Emre Edev (he/him)

Deputy Director

NYC Council, Finance Division

212-482-2915

Hi Thomas:
We received your email, and I will answer what I can:

..�.. requiring residents to clean under this code during the "established routing hour of 8am-8:59am" and I believe 6pm-7pm, �..

The schedule is correct based on your address:  8:00AM�9:00AM and 6:00 PM�7:00 PM daily
(see below)

�Requiring homeowners to clean the curb mornings and evenings, seven days a week is impossible to abide by. This code 16 should be repealed. �

Council Member Susan Zhuang is a member of the �Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management�,

https://nycadmincode.readthedocs.io/t16/c01/index.html

section 16-118
2. (a) Every owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or person in charge of any building or premises shall keep and cause to be kept the sidewalk, flagging and curbstone abutting said building or premises free from obstruction and nuisances of every kind, and shall keep said sidewalks, flagging, curbstones, and air shafts, areaways, backyards, courts and alleys free from garbage, refuse, rubbish, litter, debris and other offensive material. Such persons shall also remove garbage, refuse, rubbish, litter, debris and other offensive material between the curbstone abutting the building or premises and the roadway area extending one and one-half feet from the curbstone into the street on which the building or premises front. Such persons shall not, however, be responsible for cleaning the garbage, refuse, rubbish, litter, debris and other offensive material which accumulates at catch basins located within the one and one-half foot distance from the curbstone into the street.

We will review Code 16 (Title 16 � Section 16-118)

Subject: [EXTERNAL] Council District 43




Dear Susan Zhuang,
     share with City Council Members
    NYC Council Member
    District 43 Brooklyn

        Today I spoke with a gentleman from the office of Assemblyman William Colton about a summons I received and was referred to your office since I reside in Council District 43. The summons was for not "cleaning debris 18 inches from the curb" apparently there is a code, sanitation provision,title 16 requiring residents to clean under this code during the "established routing hour of 8am-8:59am" and I believe 6pm-7pm, every day.

    I live on a residential block that always has a vehicle in front of the home that traps the trash around the tires and underneath, and also living downwind from a Commercial Street, "Kings Highway" which is always disgustingly filthy with steady stream of litter coming down the block.  I am 79 years old and constantly sweeping the front of my house and picking up litter, where possible.  Requiring homeowners to clean the curb mornings and evenings, seven days a week is impossible to abide by. This code 16 should be repealed.

    Mr. Colton's staffer was aware of this issue but passed the buck to you, Council Member Suzan Zhuang, saying the City Council has the authority to challenge this " sanitation provision,title 16" regulation. But I also think all NYS and NYC elected officials should be working together when there is a glaring injustice. After all NYC is in NYS.

    I was told that The Department of Sanitation can pass this regulation, without NYC Council approval, that penalize those the least responsible for the Cities litter and garbage problem. It's time to intervene on behalf of those not causing the problem and focus on the root causes. And this would be the job of the NYC Council and the NYS Assembly when a Department is out of step with its mission and is overly excessive with its regulatory authority.


Thomas Menake

Subject: Tenant Harassment
To: <THPT@hpd.nyc.gov<mailto:THPT@hpd.nyc.gov>>

Dear THPT,

I hope this email finds you well.

I would like to file a complaint against my landlord who has been harassing me.

- The hot water has been turned off since 3/22/2025
- The electricity to my apartment has been turned off since 4/29/2025 around 5:30 am.
- He disconnected the radiators last year, although there are space heaters, they were not sufficient to heat the apartment due to the lack of insulation and often they would flip the breaker.  In those cases I would have to wait hours and sometimes days for them to flip the breaker back..
- There had been on-going construction without protection from dust and smell from getting into the apartment.
-He refused to replace the gas stove and we had a close call with gas poisoning.  He did remove the stove eventually with intervention from a 3rd party.
- He has made multiple buyout offers but calls them move-out incentives
- He dragged his feet on basic repairs as I have not had access to a functioning kitchen in months.
-He poured an unidentified red liquid into my apartment.  It evaporated within an hour, had a faint glue smell and made me sick.  I would often find a greasy substance on door handles/locks.  This scares me the most as I don't know what kind of poison I have come in contact with and what other substance I don't know about.   There is only a layer thin dry wall with the rest of the house with cracks though fixtures and pipes.  There are often strange smells coming from these areas as if poisonous gas is being piped through them .   I often get headaches and fevers.  I am the last one here, I am scared, and at my wits end.

I called the cops a number of times (a couple of times through transfer by 311)  but they were not happy, I would say even angry at me for involving them, and frankly do not view what he has done as crimes or assault.   A few of them flatly advised me to move.

I may need to move asap for my own safety but he should not be able to get away with this so freely.

Many thanks for your help,
Candice
1068 62nd street

From: Gil, Carolina <CGil@council.nyc.gov<mailto:CGil@council.nyc.gov>>
Sent: Friday, March 7, 2025 3:10 PM
To: Gil, Carolina <CGil@council.nyc.gov<mailto:CGil@council.nyc.gov>>; Rosenberg, Jonathan <JRosenberg@council.nyc.gov<mailto:JRosenberg@council.nyc.gov>>
Subject: FY26 Submission Process for Council Member Discretionary Capital Funding

Good Afternoon Budget Team,
Below is an overview of this year�s process for submitting Council Member Discretionary Capital funding, along with other key details.
Capital Funding Submission
Council Members have a total of $5 million in discretionary capital funding to allocate and must submit their proposed projects accordingly.   If Council Members want to fund Non-City projects, please be aware that Non-City projects are reviewed in CapGrants, and must receive approval from OMB, which can lead to either a partial approval or full denial of funding. This year�s submission template has been designed to account for such scenarios.
The attached "FY26 Council Members Capital Template" contains three worksheets:

  1.  Council Members � Use this to list the $5 million in discretionary capital allocations.
  2.  Ranked Backup Projects � If any Non-City projects are included in the Council Members worksheet, please list alternative projects that could replace them in case of partial or non-approval. If your submission contains only City projects, this worksheet does not need to be completed. Backup projects should be similar in value to the non-city projects included on the $5 million list.
  3.  Speaker Ranked Priorities � Enter up to eight projects in order of priority, including those from any delegation list or any other project the Member would like to indicate as a priority to the Speaker.  If you would like the Speaker to fund a portion of a project you are providing funding for on your $5 million list please only include the amount you want the Speaker to cover, not the entire amount you want to be funded in total.

Important Notes on Non-City Projects
If your submission includes Non-City projects, you must notify OMB through the CapGrants system to indicate your interest. Failing to check the appropriate box may result in OMB deprioritizing the project�s review, potentially delaying approval. Additionally, any issues raised by OMB must be addressed before a Non-City project can be included in the budget. The responsibility falls on the Member�s office to coordinate with the respective groups to resolve these issues, as OMB does not directly notify groups of project-related concerns. If you need assistance with reopening the portal for groups your Council Member wishes to fund, please reach out to me.

Submission Deadline
All Capital Funding Lists must be submitted by 5:00 PM on Monday, April 14th. If your office is participating in Participatory Budgeting, please submit your list by this deadline, using a placeholder of $1 million for those projects to be included from Participatory Budgeting. Once the voting results are available, you may update your submission with the winning projects. After receiving submissions, we will meet to address any eligibility concerns. (Meeting scheduling link will be sent separately)

Attachments for Reference

  1.  FY26 Council Members Capital Template � Please carefully review the template and use the same format for submission
  2.  NYC Schools List � Please make sure to include the Building and school codes for any school projects that you are submitting.  Schools located within leased spaced are sometimes not be eligible for technology funding. That determination is made later in the capital review process with most schools being deemed eligible for technology. Schools located within leased spaces are not eligible for construction funding.  Charter Schools operating within a DOE space are treated as city projects just like any other school projects.  Charter Schools operating within a space which they own must apply via CapGrants for capital funding. Charter Schools operating in spaces not owned by themselves or DOE are usually ineligible for any non-technology capital funding. Technology projects may be admissible via the general city process, please reach out to myself with specific examples.
  3.  Non-City Eligibility Guidelines � A resource for groups seeking meetings with your office, serving as a preliminary checklist to assess project eligibility.
  4.  CapGrants Portal Access � You can log in at Home Page - Dynamics 365<https://gcc02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fombprod01.crm9.dynamics.com%2Fmain.aspx%3Fappid%3D743579ec-ef91-ed11-aad1-001dd804fbd7%26forceUCI%3D1%26pagetype%3Dcustom%26name%3Dcapgrant_app_d4b4e&data=05%7C01%7Clachanced%40omb.nyc.gov%7C10af057eba7f4d3d24e908db15001fe3%7C69fa79eee93a4ddfb8d1fbf15f49f820%7C0%7C0%7C638126862532785639%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=1nOd3t78EfSh5lmaNUkYqDYczbo9imYpbvWXh7QcMQw%3D&reserved=0> using your Council email and the same password as your email account.
  5.  CapGrants Reference Graphic � A visual guide to marking projects for OMB review.
  6.  CapGrants training materials

Please let me know if you have any questions.


Regards,

Carolina Gil | Principal Capital Analyst
New York City Council Finance Division
cgil@council.nyc.gov<mailto:cgil@council.nyc.gov>  | (O) 212-482-2936

Subject: (5/19/25 - 5p) CM Expense Discretionary - Second Round Submission Deadline - CM Zhuang
Importance: High

Good Afternoon CM Zhuang�s office,
I am writing to inform you that both the Finance Division and the General Counsel�s office have completed their initial review of your FY26 Discretionary Funding Requests. You may now log back into the online system to review your original submissions and make any changes you see fit. When logging back in, you will find the awards located in the �FY2026 Council Member Designations� table on your dashboard. We have given each payment a unique Preliminary MOCS ID#, in addition to listing any issues or concerns we may have with the designation. Please see Finance and/or General Counsel Comment sections for awards that were not cleared/approved by either office.
In an effort to expedite the finalization of your list, we are asking that you please use the �CM Change Notes� section in the feedback area of the payment form to notate any fields you have changed. (Ex. CM Change Notes: POF & Amount�.OR�.Source, Program Name & POF)
** In the event your office needs to move awards between sources/pots, you must temporarily reduce the amount of the awards being moved in order to make funds available within those pots for the change. Also, please do not forget to update the �Fund� section to reflect the new source/pot.
[cid:image001.png@01DBBDDC.81E75D80]

Submission Deadline: We ask that you please submit your list for Round 2 review no later than 5p on Monday, May 19th, 2025.

As always if you have any questions or concerns please reach out to Paul Scimone PScimone@council.nyc.gov<mailto:PScimone@council.nyc.gov> or James Reyes JReyes@council.nyc.gov<mailto:JReyes@council.nyc.gov>.
Thank you,
savanna

From: tamtamc <tamtamc@gmail.com<mailto:tamtamc@gmail.com>>
Date: Thu, May 1, 2025 at 6:04?PM
Subject: Tenant Harassment
To: <THPT@hpd.nyc.gov<mailto:THPT@hpd.nyc.gov>>

Dear THPT,

I hope this email finds you well.

I would like to file a complaint against my landlord who has been harassing me.

- The hot water has been turned off since 3/22/2025
- The electricity to my apartment has been turned off since 4/29/2025 around 5:30 am.
- He disconnected the radiators last year, although there are space heaters, they were not sufficient to heat the apartment due to the lack of insulation and often they would flip the breaker.  In those cases I would have to wait hours and sometimes days for them to flip the breaker back..
- There had been on-going construction without protection from dust and smell from getting into the apartment.
-He refused to replace the gas stove and we had a close call with gas poisoning.  He did remove the stove eventually with intervention from a 3rd party.
- He has made multiple buyout offers but calls them move-out incentives
- He dragged his feet on basic repairs as I have not had access to a functioning kitchen in months.
-He poured an unidentified red liquid into my apartment.  It evaporated within an hour, had a faint glue smell and made me sick.  I would often find a greasy substance on door handles/locks.  This scares me the most as I don't know what kind of poison I have come in contact with and what other substance I don't know about.   There is only a layer thin dry wall with the rest of the house with cracks though fixtures and pipes.  There are often strange smells coming from these areas as if poisonous gas is being piped through them .   I often get headaches and fevers.  I am the last one here, I am scared, and at my wits end.

I called the cops a number of times (a couple of times through transfer by 311)  but they were not happy, I would say even angry at me for involving them, and frankly do not view what he has done as crimes or assault.   A few of them flatly advised me to move.

I may need to move asap for my own safety but he should not be able to get away with this so freely.

Many thanks for your help,
Candice
1068 62nd street

column5:
Hello All:

�I am following up on these budget requests form TAOTS - are there next steps?�

There�s no next step for schools right now..  The state budget was just handed down from Albany last week, and every Council District is involved with looking at their numbers right now.  We will have nothing to report until June 30, 2025.

�..��we invited Councilmember Zhuang to come to TAOTs in May�

My apologies, can you please resubmit that request?  I just did a search and nothing came up for TAOTS (unless it�s the same date/time as the BSI request).

Regards,

Stanley Ng
Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang
6514-20th Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11204

Hi all,
I hope it has been a good spring. I am following up on these budget requests form TAOTS - are there next steps? Additionally we invited Councilmember Zhuang to come to TAOTs in May. Is that a possibility, and how can I finalize the schedule?

Thank you,
Lizzie

Cc: Kelly Clancy <kelly.a.clancy@gmail.com<mailto:kelly.a.clancy@gmail.com>>; Josephin Sportella Giusto e <JSportellaGiusto@schools.nyc.gov<mailto:JSportellaGiusto@schools.nyc.gov>>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Follow up to Parent Breakfast - PS 682


Dear Susan and Stanley,

I am the PTO President of PS 682- The Academy of Talented Scholars (TAOTS). I am writing on behalf of our parent community to express our thanks for your continued support to our school. Thank you for hosting the parent leader breakfast on January 17- I wish I could have been there in person, but our Title 1 PAC Chairperson Kelly Clancy was able to attend. I really appreciate how you have made yourselves available to hear from parents and engage thoughtfully with issues facing the schools in your district.

I wanted to follow up and share the TAOTS wish list for your consideration. There is overlap with the capital needs of BSI, with whom we share a building. We are so grateful for your continued support to our school community.

Building Needs:

1) HVAC system - our building heating and cooling system is extremely uneven and unreliable and in need of an upgrade. It results in students and staff tolerating significant discomfort in both hot and cold weather.

2) We would like to add 2 more refillable water stations in the building.

3) We would like to upgrade our outdoor playground area. Our courtyard has a hard surface and we worry about the safety of our students when they play outside. We also think there are ways to improve the design of our courtyard so that it improves the organization and enjoyment of the community space by all the schools in our building. We understand that funds may be available from your office to support the upgrade of our courtyard. Principal Sportella is included in this email and she is ready to take the next steps to claim the funds and move the project forward.

Support for Enrichment at TAOTS:

The TAOTS parent community is interested in using the discretionary funds that may be available to our school to pursue a swimming partnership with the JCH in our neighborhood, or to expand our after school chess program which is very popular with our students but has limited staff available to teach.
Thank you for your consideration and support
Lizzie Elston
TAOTS PTO President

Where can I get more help?

 � The Tenant Helpline is a free resource available to all New Yorkers, no matter your immigration status.
Tenant Helpline Specialists at the NYC Public Engagement Unit provide 1-on-1 support, in multiple
languages, to tenants experiencing harassment from their landlord. Call 311 and ask for the Tenant
Helpline. Learn more at nyc.gov/TenantHelpline.


I believe the 311# is up 24 hours.

To: Ng, Stanley
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: Tenant Harassment


CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Report suspected phishing emails with the Phish Alert Button or forward them to phish@oti.nyc.gov<mailto:phish@oti.nyc.gov> as an attachment.


FYI.  Is this the correct email?

Thank you.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: tamtamc <tamtamc@gmail.com<mailto:tamtamc@gmail.com>>
Date: Thu, May 1, 2025 at 6:04?PM
Subject: Tenant Harassment
To: <THPT@hpd.nyc.gov<mailto:THPT@hpd.nyc.gov>>

Dear THPT,

I hope this email finds you well.

I would like to file a complaint against my landlord who has been harassing me.

- The hot water has been turned off since 3/22/2025
- The electricity to my apartment has been turned off since 4/29/2025 around 5:30 am.
- He disconnected the radiators last year, although there are space heaters, they were not sufficient to heat the apartment due to the lack of insulation and often they would flip the breaker.  In those cases I would have to wait hours and sometimes days for them to flip the breaker back..
- There had been on-going construction without protection from dust and smell from getting into the apartment.
-He refused to replace the gas stove and we had a close call with gas poisoning.  He did remove the stove eventually with intervention from a 3rd party.
- He has made multiple buyout offers but calls them move-out incentives
- He dragged his feet on basic repairs as I have not had access to a functioning kitchen in months.
-He poured an unidentified red liquid into my apartment.  It evaporated within an hour, had a faint glue smell and made me sick.  I would often find a greasy substance on door handles/locks.  This scares me the most as I don't know what kind of poison I have come in contact with and what other substance I don't know about.   There is only a layer thin dry wall with the rest of the house with cracks though fixtures and pipes.  There are often strange smells coming from these areas as if poisonous gas is being piped through them .   I often get headaches and fevers.  I am the last one here, I am scared, and at my wits end.

I called the cops a number of times (a couple of times through transfer by 311)  but they were not happy, I would say even angry at me for involving them, and frankly do not view what he has done as crimes or assault.   A few of them flatly advised me to move.

I may need to move asap for my own safety but he should not be able to get away with this so freely.

Many thanks for your help,
Candice
1068 62nd street

column4: 2025 Legislative Breakfast! within Community School District 21. You .
column5:
RSVP-4/8/25

Good Afternoon,

You are cordially invited to our 2025 Legislative Breakfast! The purpose of this breakfast is to network within Community School District 21. You will have the opportunity to informally exchange/share ideas for your schools with other school representatives and Elected Officials.  The breakfast will take place on:

Friday, May 9, 2025, 10 AM - 12 PM at:
John Dewey High School
50 Avenue X, Brooklyn, NY 11223

We will also be making special presentations to our Elected Officials & Parent Coordinators who continuously support District 21.

Please R.S.V.P. by May 1, 2025 to CEC21@schools.nyc.gov<mailto:CEC21@schools.nyc.gov> or https://forms.office.com/r/u1hqmuYkSp?origin=lprLink<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/forms.office.com/r/u1hqmuYkSp?origin=lprLink__;!!Pe07lN5AjA!TiI2GnDQLxIJhSpz5jHeNvDHdpDut9Q-F3dfbCYSlHD-Lxp8F1aNzqpWRulG5COc-uOcu7QhBsvpDOrv9kU1xPx8Rjyvu66wfg$>

*As seating is limited, people who hold the position of Principals, PTA President, Parent Coordinator, and UFT Chapter Leader are invited to attend. Again, we apologize, however, seating is very limited and we cannot accommodate substitutions.*

 We are looking forward to seeing you and thank you for being a part of our great community!




With the Kindest Regards and Best Wishes,

Thank you so much for the quick repair.

Tenants on the block called last week when the hydrant stopped leaking.

Essentially, When the hydrant(s) leak on that block (or even 1 or 2 blocks away), there�s a drop in water pressure, and either not enough water is reaching the household, or black water is coming out.

Is there a 311# complaint for this, or who to reach out to research this water pressure issue (if it is an issue).

This is the 3rd time in 2 months we have received calls from that area � apparently, the residents in that area know to look for leaking hydrants when there�s a drop in water pressure.

Regards,

Stanley Ng

To: District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov<mailto:District43@council.nyc.gov>>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Request for Assistance with NYC DOT Street Opening Permit Denial



Dear Council Member Zhuang,



My name is Peter Lambrakis, and I am the new owner of a 20-unit multifamily property in Dyker Heights address: 929 71st Street Brooklyn, NY 11228.



I am seeking your assistance regarding the denial of a street opening permit by NYC DOT for a critical gas service upgrade approved by National Grid.



The work is essential to replace outdated plumbing, gas, heat, and hot water systems, addressing existing violations and improving tenant quality of life. National Grid�s load letter request was submitted prior to learning about the street�s protected status following recent paving. The denial of this permit is causing delays that create undue hardship for both me and my tenants. My understanding is that the street cannot be interrupted for 5 years but I was unaware of the planned street paving work prior to purchasing the property or starting the essential work.

I have attached the permit application, load letter request, and the DOT denial notice for your reference. I kindly request your support in communicating with DOT to explore possible solutions so this urgent work can proceed.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Peter Lambrakis
9902 Fort Hamilton Parkway

Brooklyn, NY 11209
718-781-1063

Attachments:

  *   DOB Boiler replacement permit approved on September 24th 2024
  *   Load Letter Request accepted by National Grid on October 4th 2024
  *   DOT Denial Notice received October 21st 2024

On Fri, May 2, 2025 at 10:34?AM District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov<mailto:District43@council.nyc.gov>> wrote:
Hi James:
What a wonderful idea!  We need more kids like Billie to care about the environment, especially at the age of 8.
Since Billie attends K-5 during the day, a meeting would have to be after school or a weekend.
In the meantime, We have a Movie Night 10 hours at Seth Low tonight (Friday 05/02/25 - see flyer) � and an event this Sunday (see attached � 05/04/25). Feel free to bring the family to either event � and say HELLO.

BTW: May I have your address for our records?  I will check with the scheduler on Monday about a possible meeting.

Stanley Ng

6514-20th Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11204

From: James Pool <jamiepool@gmail.com<mailto:jamiepool@gmail.com>>
Sent: Friday, May 2, 2025 10:09 AM
To: szhuang@council.nyc.com<mailto:szhuang@council.nyc.com>; District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov<mailto:District43@council.nyc.gov>>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Banning Styrofoam and Plastic Egg Cartons

Dear Council Member Zhuang,
My name is James Pool, and I have been a resident of New York City for over 20 years. My daughter, Billie, attends third grade in the New York City public school system, along with her little brother, Freddy, who is in kindergarten.
Billie is a precocious and caring girl.  For her year-end school project she has chosen to start a petition to ban Styrofoam and plastic egg cartons in New York City.  Billie believes that this will help reduce a common source of waste at little cost to New Yorkers � cardboard egg cartons are inexpensive and work great.  Billie hopes that banning Styrofoam and plastic egg cartons will encourage people to think about the impact of single-use plastic and to make more sustainable decisions when possible.
Billie has started a petition to garner support for a ban on environmentally harmful egg cartons, and I am reaching out in the hope that you will support Billie�s efforts to reduce harmful waste in New York City by amplifying her message and sharing her petition through whatever means you can.
https://www.change.org/BanBadEggCartonsNYC<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.change.org/BanBadEggCartonsNYC__;!!Pe07lN5AjA!Uy7fCLcKr7Mkwfxrs9w20n9pyRtx3stuU3waJLbs-bgSkiN-sTHYKcReb76PVJQ5p4gW95AKxVuRdwFDN0GHDt-JpG8$>
Billie would also welcome the chance to speak with you to learn more about her cause and about advocacy more broadly.  We know that your time is valuable, but it would mean the world to her to get the opportunity to understand how ordinary citizens can improve our city and the world.
Thank you,
Billie Pool, age 8
And her dad, James Pool

From: Andres Juarez <ajuarez810@gmail.com>
Sent: Thursday, May 1, 2025 10:40 AM
To: District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov>
Cc: Angelica Bove <apurpero@aol.com>; Bing Long Gao <bingl.gao@gmail.com>; Chenzi <ipistone@yahoo.com>; Christina Cho <ccho.mdeng@gmail.com>; Gerta Bircaj <gertabircaj@icloud.com>; Greta Salazar Villacis <gsv1105@gmail.com>; Jenna Lin <lin_xiaojing@yahoo.com>; Jenyfer Castillo <jenyferccg@gmail.com>; Karen Chen <karenchen2018@gmail.com>; Karen Li <Karenli_919@hotmail.com>; Lin Michael Deng <mdeng211@gmail.com>; Maggie <Ymnhk86@yahoo.com>; Melissa Li <melissali1012@gmail.com>; Michelle Lopez <michellelopez10@gmail.com>; Olivia <Jingchen0315@gmail.com>; rubiethherrera29@icloud.com; Sindy Lopez <Lopez.sindy@live.com>; Ting <mumunan0820@gmail.com>; Wang Katrina <wangkatrina9@gmail.com>; Winni Chan <cwinni20@gmail.com>; Ying Ying Jiang <yjiang841@gmail.com>; yuehuayuan123@yahoo.com
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Meeting Request Re: P.S. 176 (Brooklyn, NY): Dangerous Conditions re Asbestos Due to School Construction Work (SZ)

Dear Ms. Susan Zhuang, NYC (Councilmember for District 43rd),

As you may know, my name is Andres Juarez and I'm a parent of children attending P.S. 176 The Ovington School located at 1225 Bay Ridge Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11219.

A delegation of P.S. 176 parent representatives and I would like to meet with you and your team, in-person, to further explain our continued concerns in connection with the above-referenced matter.  Please let us know your earliest availability so that we can talk and you can better understand our concerns.  Among other things, attached is a flyer with questions that we are seeking answers to from the P.S. 176 principal Elizabeth Culkin.

In connection with the NYC School Construction Authority's school construction work at P.S. 176, I have written several emails, and letters dated March 10, 2025, March 21, 2025 and most recently a letter dated April 16, 2025.  I have requested various documents, including the documents related to the P.S. 176's AHERA management plan.  My letter of April 16, 2025 is attached for ease of reference (see pages 6 and 7 regarding the requested documents).

As of today, I have not received any meaningful response from anyone.  No one has provided the documents that we have been requesting since the beginning.  The P.S. 176 principal Elizabeth Culkin continues to not be transparent and has not yet provided any of the documents requested regarding, among other things, the friable asbestos disturbance and exposure at our P.S. 176 school. Therefore, we don't have any actual data/information regarding the asbestos disturbance and exposure that our children, teachers and other school staff were already subjected to and allowed to endure.

I understand that the NYC SCA school construction work at P.S. 176 is now underway and that they have provided a new date of completion of August 2025.  However, that does not alleviate the seriousness of the friable disturbance and exposure of asbestos that the P.S. 176 children, teachers and other school staff were already subjected to and allowed to endure.

We want to prevent for our P.S. 176 school (or any other school) to be in a similar or same situation, now or in the future.  Therefore, for the health and safety of everyone, an investigation must be conducted and hold, the DOE/NYC Public Schools, DSF, NYC SCA, P.S. 176 and its principal Ms. Elizabeth Culkin, accountable for the many failures, including but not limited to:  (1) the failure to act in the best interest of the children, (2) the failure to take action that allowed the worsening conditions of the disturbed (friable) asbestos, (3) the failure to protect the children, teachers and other school staff, (4) the failure to comply with the law (e.g. AHERA), (5) the failure to inform and provide notification to parents, teachers and other school staff of the disturbance and exposure of friable asbestos, (6) the failure to provide all of the documents requested; and (7) the attempts to stop me from sharing the information related to the NYC SCA school construction work in connection with the resulting friable asbestos disturbance and exposure at P.S. 176.

We want to ensure that P.S. 176 is in compliance with AHERA (federal law); and provide us (parents) with the documents and information that we so desperately have been asking for and need in order to understand the severity of the asbestos disturbance and exposure at P.S. 176.  Furthermore, we ask that you take any other action deemed necessary to help our children and us (parents).

Respectfully,

Andres Juarez
Parent of Children Attending
P.S. 176 The Ovington School

column4: (05/02/25) -  Banning Styrofoam and Plastic Egg Cartons
column5:
Hi James:
What a wonderful idea!  We need more kids like Billie to care about the environment, especially at the age of 8.
Since Billie attends K-5 during the day, a meeting would have to be after school or a weekend.
In the meantime, We have a Movie Night 10 hours at Seth Low tonight (Friday 05/02/25 - see flyer) � and an event this Sunday (see attached � 05/04/25). Feel free to bring the family to either event � and say HELLO.

BTW: May I have your address for our records?  I will check with the scheduler on Monday about a possible meeting.

Stanley Ng
Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang
6514-20th Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11204
Phone:  718-307-7151

From: James Pool <jamiepool@gmail.com>
Sent: Friday, May 2, 2025 10:09 AM
To: szhuang@council.nyc.com; District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Banning Styrofoam and Plastic Egg Cartons

Dear Council Member Zhuang,
My name is James Pool, and I have been a resident of New York City for over 20 years. My daughter, Billie, attends third grade in the New York City public school system, along with her little brother, Freddy, who is in kindergarten.
Billie is a precocious and caring girl.  For her year-end school project she has chosen to start a petition to ban Styrofoam and plastic egg cartons in New York City.  Billie believes that this will help reduce a common source of waste at little cost to New Yorkers � cardboard egg cartons are inexpensive and work great.  Billie hopes that banning Styrofoam and plastic egg cartons will encourage people to think about the impact of single-use plastic and to make more sustainable decisions when possible.
Billie has started a petition to garner support for a ban on environmentally harmful egg cartons, and I am reaching out in the hope that you will support Billie�s efforts to reduce harmful waste in New York City by amplifying her message and sharing her petition through whatever means you can.
https://www.change.org/BanBadEggCartonsNYC<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.change.org/BanBadEggCartonsNYC__;!!Pe07lN5AjA!Uy7fCLcKr7Mkwfxrs9w20n9pyRtx3stuU3waJLbs-bgSkiN-sTHYKcReb76PVJQ5p4gW95AKxVuRdwFDN0GHDt-JpG8$>
Billie would also welcome the chance to speak with you to learn more about her cause and about advocacy more broadly.  We know that your time is valuable, but it would mean the world to her to get the opportunity to understand how ordinary citizens can improve our city and the world.
Thank you,
Billie Pool, age 8
And her dad, James Pool

CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Report suspected phishing emails with the Phish Alert Button or forward them to phish@oti.nyc.gov as an attachment.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: tamtamc <tamtamc@gmail.com<mailto:tamtamc@gmail.com>>
Date: Thu, May 1, 2025 at 6:04?PM
Subject: Tenant Harassment
To: <THPT@hpd.nyc.gov<mailto:THPT@hpd.nyc.gov>>


Dear THPT,

I hope this email finds you well.

I would like to file a complaint against my landlord who has been harassing me.

- The hot water has been turned off since 3/22/2025
- The electricity to my apartment has been turned off since 4/29/2025 around 5:30 am.
- He disconnected the radiators last year, although there are space heaters, they were not sufficient to heat the apartment due to the lack of insulation and often they would flip the breaker.  In those cases I would have to wait hours and sometimes days for them to flip the breaker back..
- There had been on-going construction without protection from dust and smell from getting into the apartment.
-He refused to replace the gas stove and we had a close call with gas poisoning.  He did remove the stove eventually with intervention from a 3rd party.
- He has made multiple buyout offers but calls them move-out incentives
- He dragged his feet on basic repairs as I have not had access to a functioning kitchen in months.
-He poured an unidentified red liquid into my apartment.  It evaporated within an hour, had a faint glue smell and made me sick.  I would often find a greasy substance on door handles/locks.  This scares me the most as I don't know what kind of poison I have come in contact with and what other substance I don't know about.   There is only a layer thin dry wall with the rest of the house with cracks though fixtures and pipes.  There are often strange smells coming from these areas as if poisonous gas is being piped through them .   I often get headaches and fevers.  I am the last one here, I am scared, and at my wits end.

I called the cops a number of times (a couple of times through transfer by 311)  but they were not happy, I would say even angry at me for involving them, and frankly do not view what he has done as crimes or assault.   A few of them flatly advised me to move.

I may need to move asap for my own safety but he should not be able to get away with this so freely.

Many thanks for your help,
Candice
1068 62nd street

Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: (05/01/2025) - (04/24/2025) - (04/22/2025) - Case involving Ibrokhim Abralova at 811k and Cavallero IS 281

Dear Mr. Ng,

Nasi and I want you to know that Nasi went to the 61st precinct on monday April 28, 2025 to fill out a report against Mr. Warren for his abusive and harmful acts against Ibrokhim at 811K on February 25, 2025.

Yesterday we received the Report from Detective Jose Cofresi.The report is attached. Both Nasi and I were very shocked by the Report, which states that the "investigation was completed", which it was not, and that "there was no abuse" which is not true. We spoke with Mr. Cofresi last week, and he told us that no one from the school got back to him, and he was still barred from interviewing anyone at the school. So his report is false.

We need to hold Mr. Warren accountable for his actions, and we also need to provide the Superintendents of D75, and Brooklyn, what is happening.

Please advise us on what we should do now.

Thank you.

Betsy Combier
Nasi Abralova

Hi Betsy and Nasibakhon :

We received this email and our office is reviewing.

We wanted to make sure we are on the same page based on the information in this email. We see two problems:

***MEDIA ADVISORY***



As City Faces Elevated Wildfire Risk, New York City Council Expected to Vote to Require Strategic Planning to Prevent and Mitigate Wildfires in City Parks



Council also expected to vote on legislation to preserve cap on fees restaurants are charged by delivery apps



The New York City Council is expected to vote on the following items at Thursday's Stated Meeting. All items on the Council�s agenda are subject to change. The full agenda will be available here following committee votes.



Legislation:



Requiring a Strategic Plan to Mitigate Wildfires in City Parks

New York City�s parks, greenways, and natural areas are increasingly vulnerable to brush fires, especially during extended dry spells. With over 30,000 areas of parkland, representing 14% of the City�s total land areas, the risk to these green spaces is significant. In just the first two weeks of November 2024, the FDNY responded to a record-breaking 271 fires<https://www.nyc.gov/site/fdny/news/Y11-13/fdny-releases-new-psa-during-historic-period-brush-fires-across-new-york-city#:~:text=During%20the%20time%20period%20of,in%20New%20York%20City%20history> across the city, the highest number ever recorded in such a short timeframe.



Introduction 1185-A<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7102686&GUID=E7F5D0BF-BA36-4677-863C-2A59D4581974&Options=ID|Text|&Search=int.+1185>, sponsored by Council Member Shekar Krishnan, would require the Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR) to develop a strategic plan to mitigate the occurrences of wildfires in New York City�s parks by March 1, 2026. The plan would have to be posted on DPR�s website and updated regularly. This bill would also require DPR to report annually on wildfires that occur in parks under its jurisdiction.



Preserving Limits on Fees Delivery Apps Can Charge Restaurants

The COVID-19 pandemic drove rapid growth in food delivery services. But high fees charged by food delivery apps place significant financial strain on restaurants, especially for small businesses. In response, the Council enacted legislation capping the fees that delivery platforms can charge. While this law provided critical relief, New York City is one of the last of the more than 100 cities that enacted the policy to keep it after the pandemic in the wake of lawsuits by delivery app companies. These legal challenges threatened the viability of the protections for restaurants. The following legislation preserves the existing fee caps, while allowing delivery apps to offer additional optional services for additional, limited fees. It allows restaurants to avoid mandatory, exorbitant fees and instead opt into enhanced services, such as marketing efforts by the apps on behalf of the restaurant, in exchange for a higher fee. The bill also establishes strong protections for those who do not opt in, by clearly defining the basic services that must remain subject to capped rates.



Introduction 762-B<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=6632578&GUID=874ADD05-D520-4896-BA03-79A18349EADD&Options=ID|Text|&Search=762>, sponsored by Council Member Rafael Salamanca, Jr., would maintain limits on the fees that third-party delivery services can charge restaurants, while allowing apps to provide optional enhanced services for an additional fee of 20 percent. It would only permit charging an enhanced service fee, however, if the delivery service also offers the option to purchase a basic service plan at a cost no higher than the current fee limits that includes delivery services and being listed and discoverable on the third-party platform.



Tracking Student Access to School Libraries and Librarians

Introduction 1125-A<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7029046&GUID=C004ADBB-8D76-4AB7-837C-86896FA4E18C&Options=ID|Text|&Search=int.+1125>, sponsored by Council Member Lincoln Restler, would require the Department of Education to report annually the number of licensed and non-licensed school librarians at each school, the number of school libraries, and other data related to student access to library staff and facilities, including compliance with state staffing requirements.



Annually Auditing Contract Awards to Minority and Women Business Enteprises

Introduction 23-A,<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=6505382&GUID=A9D5DD2A-1D82-4AEC-A03F-156EE1952881&Options=ID|Text|&Search=int.+23> sponsored by Majority Whip Selvena Brooks-Powers, would require the City Comptroller to publish an annual report that indicates the total share of City procurement contracts that were awarded to minority- and women-owned business enterprises (MWBE�s) for the most recent fiscal year. The report would include information regarding the contract value, awarding agency, and demographics of the MWBEs.



Requiring Taxis and For-Hire Vehicles to Display Signs for Passengers to Look Out for Cyclists

Introduction 193-A<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=6557538&GUID=FEBD037C-7B97-4641-8C11-496654004F71&Options=ID|Text|&Search=int.+193>, sponsored by Council Member Jennifer Guti�rrez, would require all taxis and for-hire vehicles to prominently display a sign on all rear passenger doors warning passengers to look for cyclists before opening the door. The signs would be provided to drivers and vehicle owners at no cost by the Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC).



Designating May 10 as Chinese American Railroad Worker Memorial Day

Resolution 844<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7287072&GUID=28D92BDD-2B1D-4BF9-8867-68E44F3FBE4A&Options=&Search=>, sponsored by Council Member Susan Zhuang, would recognize May 10th annually as Chinese American Railroad Workers Memorial Day in New York City. Nearly 12,000 Chinese immigrants were employed by the Central Pacific Railroad Company to build a transcontinental railroad. Nearly 1,200 Chinese railroad workers died from accidents, avalanches, and explosions during this work.



Recognizing Life, Legacy and Achievements of Judith Jamison

Resolution 741<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7137388&GUID=D05EC957-19EB-43C6-A047-A47520E406B5&Options=&Search=>, sponsored by Council Member Carlina Rivera, would designate May 10th annually as Judith Jamison Day in the City of New York to honor her life and legacy as a dancer, choreographer, and longtime artistic director of the groundbreaking Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.



Supporting the Equity in Fertility Treatment Act

Resolution 165-B<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=6557809&GUID=DF947885-DEA2-44A7-8D5B-8EFDFE15594D&Options=ID|Text|&Search=165>, sponsored by Council Member Mercedes Narcisse, would call on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, S.5545/A.885, the Equity in Fertility Treatment Act.



Calling for State Legislation to Cap the Cost of Routine Medical Procedures

Resolution 822-A<https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7281636&GUID=7CBBF20D-2C9B-48CF-BD52-7A7DABF7F745&Options=ID|Text|&Search=822>, sponsored by Council Member Lynn Schulman, would call on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, S.705/A.2140, which would cap the amount people pay for non-complicated, routine medical procedures at 150% of the cost paid by Medicare for those same services.



Land Use:

102-51 Queens Boulevard Rezoning � a private application to facilitate a new 17-story, mixed-use building with approximately 216 residential units, 54 of which will be permanently affordable under Mandatory Inclusionary Housing (MIH), in Council Member Lynn Schulman�s district.

Sent: Tuesday, April 1, 2025 12:58 PM

Subject: Chinese RR Workers Reso



https://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7287072&GUID=28D92BDD-2B1D-4BF9-8867-68E44F3FBE4A<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=7287072&GUID=28D92BDD-2B1D-4BF9-8867-68E44F3FBE4A__;!!LAh5qUgpm5Y!EtqBswKun7x3GNsGJK3L9dbZjOvRG8iDzbX3jeT6JTFn9JggDwvKasGIygp5KaXEUVU12Os35RRQLSCzVOWPKdDqwWY$>



Public Hearing:  Committee on Cultural Affairs

                                Tuesday, April 8 at 10:00 AM



Xavier San Miguel

Director of Legislation

Office of Council Member Susan Zhuang

District Office: (718) 307-7151

Cell Phone: (917) 952-0157

Email: xsanmiguel@council.nyc.gov<mailto:xsanmiguel@council.nyc.gov>

_____



Whereas, The nearly 2,000-mile Transcontinental Railroad, which shortened travel time across the United States (U.S) from six months to one week, was completed on May 10, 1869, when the Central Pacific Railroad Company and the Union Pacific Railroad Company linked railroad tracks with a golden spike at Promontory Summit, Utah; and

Whereas, One of the earliest proponents for the construction of a transcontinental railroad was New York City (NYC) entrepreneur Asa Whitney, who in 1845 presented a proposal to the U.S. Congress for a railroad running from Lake Michigan to the Pacific; and

Whereas, While Whitney�s initial proposal failed, it set in motion the idea of a transcontinental railroad that would be championed in the 1860s by engineer Theodore Judah, who lobbied to pass the Pacific Railroad Act in the U.S. House of Representatives on May 6, 1862, and in the U.S. Senate on June 6, 1862; and

Whereas, On July 1, 1862, President Abraham Lincoln signed into law the Pacific Railroad Act of 1862, which authorized the Central Pacific Railroad Company, co-founded by Charles Crocker, a Troy, New York native, and the Union Pacific Railroad Company, controlled by Wall Street investor Thomas Durant, to build a transcontinental railroad that would link the U.S. from east to west; and

Whereas, Work began in 1863, as the Central Pacific Railroad Company started to build its tracks in Sacramento moving east and the Union Pacific Railroad Company started to build westward from Council Bluffs, Iowa, where railroad lines were already operating from the eastern part of the country; and

Whereas, For six years, the workers of both companies toiled to lay down the rail beds, tracks, and other necessary infrastructure; and

Whereas, The workers of the Central Pacific Railroad Company initially numbered many Irish immigrants from NYC and Boston; and

Whereas, Because of difficulties in recruiting a sufficient number of workers, nearly 12,000 Chinese immigrants were employed by the Central Pacific Railroad Company and made up more than 80 percent of its workforce; and

Whereas, According to 2019 U.S. House of Representatives Resolution ( H. Res.) 165, the Chinese workers �were given the most difficult, dangerous jobs and were paid lower wages than other railroad workers� and �nearly 1,200 Chinese railroad workers died from work accidents, avalanches, and explosions while working in the Sierra Nevada Mountains�; and

Whereas, According to H. Res. 165, the Chinese workers, who once set a world record when they laid 10 miles of track in one day, were thought of as �indispensable by their foremen and were respected for their work ethic and discipline�; and

Whereas, In 2014, the U.S. Department of Labor inducted the Chinese railroad workers into the Labor Hall of Honor, noting that they �faced prejudice, low wages and social isolation,� but, in spite of these challenges, � they courageously took a stand to organize for fairer wages and safer working conditions�; and

Whereas, According to H. Res. 165, the Chinese workers� fight against unfair labor practices �set an example for the millions of Asian Americans who came to the [U.S] after them�; and

Whereas, According to H. Res. 165, �both the descendants of these workers and the wider Asian-American community view the sacrifices of the Chinese railroad workers as being integral to the creation of the vibrant and growing Asian-American community� in the U.S. today; and

Whereas, According to 2020 population figures provided by the Asian American Federation, over 600,000 Chinese and Chinese Americans live in NYC, with roughly one-third being U.S. born, one-third being naturalized citizens, and one-third being non-citizens; and

Whereas, According to those figures, roughly 40 percent of Chinese and Chinese Americans reside in Queens, with another approximately 35 percent residing in Brooklyn; and

Whereas, The considerable cultural, economic, and political contributions of New Yorkers of Chinese descent help make NYC what it is today; and

Whereas, It is fitting that the early contributions of the Chinese railroad workers also be honored and celebrated by all New Yorkers; now, therefore, be it

Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York recognizes May 10 annually as Chinese American Railroad Workers Memorial Day in New York City.



LS #18967

3/24/25

RHP

NYCDOT Mail







-------- Original message --------

From: "Ng, Stanley" <SNg@council.nyc.gov<mailto:SNg@council.nyc.gov>>

Date: 1/3/25 2:55 PM (GMT-05:00)

To: "Branch, Leroy" <lbranch@dot.nyc.gov<mailto:lbranch@dot.nyc.gov>>

Cc: District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov<mailto:District43@council.nyc.gov>>

Subject: (01/03/2025) - street signs - renaming of streets



Leroy:



Street naming, renaming of a street.



Is the time schedule accurate?  3 weeks minimum?



What are the steps to start the process?





https://www.nyc.gov/assets/brooklyncb6/downloads/pdf/city-official-co-naming-policy.pdf



7. Once the City Council passes the bill, it is given to the Mayor for his signature.

8. DOT will only honor requests for sign installation ceremonies once a local law authorizing the ceremonial name is signed by the Mayor and such requests must be made by the Council Member sponsoring the naming.

9. Requests for sign installation ceremonies must be presented to DOT at least three weeks or more in advance and DOT has final approval of this date.

10. Ceremonies should not be scheduled until the date has been confirmed by DOT.

11. DOT will install ONE street sign at DOT�s expense.  In no cases will more than one sign be installed regardless of the number of blocks named.

12. The sign will be installed at the location designated by the Council Member sponsoring the legislation and/or the family.

13. DOT will only place the sign on an existing street light pole or pole with an existing street name signs adhered to it.

14. DOT will have final approval of the placement of the sign. Replica Signs



DOT will manufacture one replica sign which is a street sign with the ceremonial name on one side.

The family and Council Member may purchase additional replica signs for $32 plus shipping and handling.

DOT will not ship the additional replica signs to the family until DOT receives full payment for the additional signs.





Stanley Ng

Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang

6514-20th Avenue

Brooklyn, NY 11204

Phone:  718-307-7151

From: Diana S <dswift302@gmail.com>
Sent: Wednesday, April 30, 2025 7:21 PM
To: District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Seth Low Park

Good evening, there seems to be a big problem with the sit on scooters in Seth Low park playground. While riding bicycles around the perimeter of the park, my daughter was almost hit by one speeding into the park. It is mostly high school aged kids riding them around the running track and soccer fields even when they are crowded with young children playing. This is an every day occurrence and an accident waiting to happen. I contacted the police and they told me to call 311 which must be a joke. There needs to be either a permanent police presence in the park, or a complete ban on scooters in the park with consequences .Please let me know who I can contact if you can not do anything to help with this issue. Thank you

Diana Swift

Hi Diana:

Our office been in contact with the Park department Enforcement people � and one of the issue that came up � is the date time that these riders are in the park.  The 311# is a tool that they use to accentuate the best time for the squad to catch the riders.

https://www.nycgovparks.org/about/urban-park-service/park-enforcement-patrol

I�m going to forward your email to that group � For the future, I would ask (encourage) you to please submit the NYC 311# (with date/time)  - and forward those 311 numbers to us immediately.  We will follow up.

Regards,

Stanley Ng
Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang
6514-20th Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11204
Phone:  718-307-7151

Yes, it will take a minimum of 3 weeks for the actual dedication.

Has the location been approved by the City Council and the Mayor? If so, then I will put you in contact with the division from DOT who handles co-naming.







NYCDOT Mail







-------- Original message --------

From: "Ng, Stanley" <SNg@council.nyc.gov<mailto:SNg@council.nyc.gov>>

Date: 1/3/25 2:55 PM (GMT-05:00)

To: "Branch, Leroy" <lbranch@dot.nyc.gov<mailto:lbranch@dot.nyc.gov>>

Cc: District43 <District43@council.nyc.gov<mailto:District43@council.nyc.gov>>

Subject: (01/03/2025) - street signs - renaming of streets



Leroy:



Street naming, renaming of a street.



Is the time schedule accurate?  3 weeks minimum?



What are the steps to start the process?





https://www.nyc.gov/assets/brooklyncb6/downloads/pdf/city-official-co-naming-policy.pdf



7. Once the City Council passes the bill, it is given to the Mayor for his signature.

8. DOT will only honor requests for sign installation ceremonies once a local law authorizing the ceremonial name is signed by the Mayor and such requests must be made by the Council Member sponsoring the naming.

9. Requests for sign installation ceremonies must be presented to DOT at least three weeks or more in advance and DOT has final approval of this date.

10. Ceremonies should not be scheduled until the date has been confirmed by DOT.

11. DOT will install ONE street sign at DOT�s expense.  In no cases will more than one sign be installed regardless of the number of blocks named.

12. The sign will be installed at the location designated by the Council Member sponsoring the legislation and/or the family.

13. DOT will only place the sign on an existing street light pole or pole with an existing street name signs adhered to it.

14. DOT will have final approval of the placement of the sign. Replica Signs



DOT will manufacture one replica sign which is a street sign with the ceremonial name on one side.

The family and Council Member may purchase additional replica signs for $32 plus shipping and handling.

DOT will not ship the additional replica signs to the family until DOT receives full payment for the additional signs.





Stanley Ng

Office Manager for D43 Council Member Susan Zhuang

6514-20th Avenue

Brooklyn, NY 11204

Phone:  718-307-7151

column5:
I�m reaching out on behalf of Inside Broadway. We would love to invite Councilmember Zhuang to a performance of our CASA show taking place at P.S. 186K (7601 19th Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11214) on Tuesday, May 20th at 5:15pm. The show will last approximately 45 minutes. I have attached a flyer about the show for more information.



If the Councilmember able to attend, we would love for her to speak to the audience of parents before the show or pass out certificates to the students afterwards. If she can only come for a portion of the show, we would be happy to adjust the schedule to accommodate her.



If she is able to come for the entire show, or just for the beginning, please arrive 5 to 10 minutes before to allow us time to prepare for your visit. Someone from our staff will be there as well; we will put you in touch with them closer to the performance date.



Please let us know if the Councilmember is able to attend. We would love to see her there!



Thank you!



Elisha Herring-Cooper (she/her)

Program Coordinator, Executive Assistant

Inside Broadway

elisha@insidebroadway.org<mailto:elisha@insidebroadway.org>

Phone: (212) 245-0710 x11
